review_title: Not the greatest place to work
pros: The area is an incredibly beautiful place to live with lots of outdoor activity options. There are SOME faculty, administrators, and staff who are working really hard to make this university a great place to work and a positive environment for students.
cons: The pay is way too low and the housing expensive and often not even available. Unless you have dual income or other sources of income it is extremely challenging to live there. There is consistent gender inequality with how the female faculty are treated and their workload relative to their pay. In the four years I was there I saw little improvement in this area even though the university brought in an external firm to assess diversity, inclusivity, and equity issues. There is a "good old boy" mentality with male faculty particularly in the sciences and environmental studies. I was bullied by a tenured male faculty member and when I tried to address my concern with his supervisor (also a tenured male faculty) he responded, "that's just the way he is". No actions were taken. A pretty toxic work environment for female faculty. There is also lots of favoritism where family members of faculty are often hired over more qualified candidates. If you are not a white male who skis and has money I suggest not considering working here. This university has so much potential but is mostly run by privileged ski bums who don't really want to provide an inclusive and welcoming environment for people who are not like them and have very little experience or vision on how to run a susccesful university.

review_title: Bad Pay Bad Leadership Bad Culture
pros: Ski area nearby and mountain biking in Summer
cons: The leadership from Chairs is really poor. Place is pretty toxic. The pay is so bad you cant even afford to rent a house.

pros: It is beautiful here and that's it.
cons: It is super expensive here.

pros: Beautiful nature, no traffic jam, cheap living price
cons: Lack of diversity, no social infrastructure, no markets or shopping malls

job_title: KWSB Production Director in Gunnison, CO
pros: I was a work-study student employee at KWSB 91.1FM the student run radio station on campus at Western Colorado University. My schedule was flexible, which allowed me to also attend school full-time.
cons: The max amount of hours that this work-study position allows is 10hours per week.

review_title: Low pay to lie about diversity issues.
pros: Useful work experience, flexible hours, access to good equipment and exclusive school events.
cons: Tremendous diversity issues that Marketing team is responsible for prettying up. Particularly discovered issues with College President Salsbury and his history of racist remarks; which required us to emphasize "talks" and other events that didn't address the core issue. Left me distracted, losing sleep when I also needed to be an effective student. Little training in things like live event coverage; often had to self-train on unpaid time.

review_title: Really enjoy the people (Faculty, Staff and Students) that work on this beautiful campus in Gunnison, Colorado.
job_title: Fitness Center Manager in Gunnison, CO
pros: Western has great benefits and working in the Campus Rec Department is a delight! The energy is positive and the members are genuine. A true pleasure to work at Western! Our best partnership is with the Athletic Department. With the addition of a new Athletic Director and the Assistant Athletic Director there are awesome vibes in our new Mountaineer Field House building.
cons: My department is pretty darn awesome. The only thing you have to remember is that because we are a small department, there are many times that your 40 hour week turns into a 50-60 or 75 hour week. While these weeks are a lot of hard work and extra effort, the department heads recognize the extra effort and are more that happy to allow comp time.

pros: The hours are awesome. The management are a great team and very fair. Very family oriented, for  example if a family member such as a child is ill at school, no questions asked the saying is go take care of your family. The management we have now is just great to work with.  The best I have ever worked for !!!!!
cons: SNOW SNOW SNOW Sometimes you have a hard time keeping with snow and trying to  get your work done. But on the whole no cons.

review_title: Denied Me My Last Pay Check, Had to Sue to Recover
pros: Fellow lecturers were good colleagues
cons: Chair of my department did not like me after I complained about the ow wage (30% under the national average).  He decided to harass me on the way out, denying me my last pay check (which is illegal).  So I had to file a lawsuit.  Several months later I received a letter asking me to sign a form agreeing never to talk publicly about the incident in return for my pay check. I declined. Months after that I finally received my pay check. I'll never work for these idiots again.

pros:
It's a beautiful area, with plentiful mountains, trails, and friendly community members (the ones who are not racist, anyway). Best team I've worked with (in my immediate department-- gets dicey as you go further up the chain), competent and amazing people.

It's small, which means that change can be easy to implement (depending on the department). Students are mostly wonderful.
cons:
First strike: sexual harassment, witnessed and independently reported by other people. I was told by HR, "He's an institution." Immediately felt worried for the students he has authority over, as he is a faculty member. 

Second strike: on the face, are always encouraging diversity, equity, and inclusion. On the other side, consistently cull non-native English speaking faculty and show complete disregard for safety. At one point, the entire black student cohort in basketball left, en masse, because white students were so hostile. In a Board of Trustees meeting, when asked to say "Black Lives Matter," one pulled an all lives matter, one said he was for it but didn't agree with the organization, one said he was surprised that the public wanted them to align with a "political group." A Board member also asked the faculty trustee what institutionalized racism was. 

Third strike: May 26th, furloughed 39 support staff who had no one to speak for them at either the faculty meeting or the Board of Trustees meeting that made the decision. Were told 6 days before the start date of June 1st that they would not be needed for the next 1/2-2 months. The total savings were $70,000. The President makes over $300k a year (and his housing is included). 

They completely disrupted 39 people's income for up to 2 months, for what amounts to a rounding error in their annual budget (worst case is $3 mil, so 2%). Meanwhile, admin patted themselves on the back for their 10% salary cuts. BoT also considered it a favor, as they selected the people who are paid the least, meaning they should (hypothetically) get paid more on unemployment with the $600 temporary Covid bonus.

Problem is, it can take 2 months to hear back about your application, if you can get one in between the other millions applying. It also doesn't pay out fully if you haven't worked at the same place for over 18 months. Since we are paid once a month, they won't see a full paycheck until August 31st (or September 30th, if you are out for 2 months). 

Fourth strike: Pay. Horrific in general, especially considering cost of living in the area. Searching for apartments reveals average rent is $1500. You can find a rathole for less, or split with someone else who can't afford to live on what they pay here. Or, get another job, as several staff and faculty do. Search for grocery prices in the two grocery stores available (Safeway and City Market) and do the math on what you would need to live comfortably here.
